name: US 441 (Newfound Gap Road)
description: A 30-mile paved road that bisects the Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Cherokee, NC and Gatlinburg, TN, featuring numerous twists and turns, scenic vistas, and a climb through diverse forest elevations.
tips: Be prepared for a winding road with numerous twists and turns
Watch for elk grazing in meadows close to the road
Do not leave food unattended in bear habitats like Chimney Tops
Expect heavy traffic and fog at higher elevations like Newfound Gap

name: Cades Cove Loop Road
description: A lush, verdant valley surrounded by mountains and one of the most popular destinations in the park. The road runs through the valley where visitors can see diverse wildlife and historic buildings.
tips: Only bicycle and foot traffic are allowed on the loop road on Wednesdays all day from early May until late September
Open to motor vehicles daily from sunrise to sunset
Weather permitting

name: Blue Ridge Parkway
description: A famous 469-mile-long scenic route that begins at the southern terminus of US 441, meandering through verdant forests as it heads north toward Virginia.
tips: Take advantage of frequent cutouts to stop and admire the scenery
The highway is exceptionally winding, requiring a slower pace

name: Roaring Fork Motor Nature Trail
description: A beautiful scenic motor trail located just outside of Gatlinburg featuring streams and historical homes.
tips: Drive slowly and be courteous of others
Keep your eyes peeled for black bears
Suitable for hikers looking to stretch their legs

name: Tremont Logging History Auto Tour
description: A gravel road tour along the Middle Prong of the Little River that focuses on the logging history of the area.
highlights: Middle Prong of the Little River
tips: The road is gravel/dirt
Most people drive this route but it can be hiked or biked
Starts at the Great Smoky Mountains Institute on Tremont Road

name: The Tail Of The Dragon
description: A world-renowned curvy and challenging road with 318 curves in an 11-mile journey. Rated as the #1 motorcycle and sports car road in the US.
tips: Not a road for leisure drivers
Highly curvy, difficult and challenging
Performance driver's favorite
Drivers can pull over at scenic areas alongside Chilhowee Lake

name: Cherokee to Kuwohi via 441
description: A scenic drive with lovely views of the Great Smoky Mountains, leading to an observation tower at the end of the trail.
tips: Please be courteous and aware while driving and nature viewing
There is a hike to an observation tower at the end of the route

name: Balsam Mountain Road
description: A road well known for its beautiful views and abundance of summer wildflowers, leading to high-elevation campgrounds and picnic areas with spectacular overlooks.
tips: Buses, motorhomes, and vans longer than 25 feet are prohibited
Passenger vehicles towing trailers are prohibited
The first 18 miles returning to Cherokee are unpaved and one-way

name: Foothills Parkway: Wear Valley to Chilhowee
description: The longest completed section of a national parkway that traverses the foothills of the northern Great Smoky Mountains.
highlights: Foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains
tips: Managed by the National Park Service as part of Great Smoky Mountains National Park
The parkway is incomplete; this is the longest current section

name: Heintooga Round Bottom Road Scenic Drive
description: A rugged and remote gravel road that weaves down into Cherokee, North Carolina, through untraveled areas of the park.
tips: Mostly a one-way gravel road
Rugged and remote road conditions

name: Roaring Fork Motor Trail
description: A narrow, paved six-mile loop of twists and turns featuring old-growth forests, historic cabins, and rushing mountain streams.
tips: Motorhomes, buses, and trailers are not permitted
Narrow road with many twists and turns
Access via traffic light #8 in Gatlinburg

name: Great Smoky Mountains Scenic Drive: Maryville to Kuwohi
description: An extensive scenic drive that traverses from Maryville to the high elevation point of Kuwohi.
tips: This trail has significant elevation gain (7,867 ft)

name: Cataloochee
description: A remote mountain valley rich in history and wildlife. Once a community of 1,200 people, it now features preserved churches, schools, and homes alongside elk and deer.
tips: Requires driving on a well-maintained gravel road for two miles
Best time for wildlife is in the morning and evenings around open fields
Follow signs 11 miles past the I-40 entrance ramp area
